articles.headline: Some in G.O.P. Who Deserted Donald Trump Over Lewd Tape Are Returning
articles.snippet: Several House or Senate members reversed themselves and are again supporting Mr. Trump to try to keep Hillary Clinton out of the White House.
articles.abstract: Several House or Senate members reversed themselves and are again supporting Mr. Trump to try to keep Hillary Clinton out of the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stung by a fierce backlash from Donald J. Trump’s ardent supporters, four Republican members of Congress who had made headlines for demanding that Mr. Trump leave the presidential race retreated quietly this week, conceding that they would still probably vote for the man they had excoriated just days before.

articles.headline: In City Built by Immigrants, Immigration Is the Defining Political Issue
articles.snippet: Many residents of Hazleton, Pa., who are losing ground, including Democrats, back Mr. Trump. Many who are prospering, including Republicans, support Clinton.
articles.abstract: Many residents of Hazleton, Pa., who are losing ground, including Democrats, back Mr. Trump. Many who are prospering, including Republicans, support Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAZLETON, Pa. — Thousands of Dominicans have poured into this little city in eastern Pennsylvania since 2001 to work in the food plants and warehouses on the edge of town, where the highway to New York meets the highway to Philadelphia.

articles.headline: Snap Is Said to Pick Bankers for an I.P.O.
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs would help lead the most eagerly awaited new internet stock offering since Twitter.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs would help lead the most eagerly awaited new internet stock offering since Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The newest generation of technology darlings has signaled that it is about to come of age: Snapchat, the messaging service beloved by teenagers, is preparing to step out into the public markets.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Chief Abruptly Steps Down
articles.snippet: He has been mired in a scandal involving sham accounts set up by bank employees. The bank’s president will succeed him.
articles.abstract: He has been mired in a scandal involving sham accounts set up by bank employees. The bank’s president will succeed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scandal engulfing Wells Fargo toppled its chairman and chief executive on Wednesday, as John G. Stumpf announced his departure from the company, effective immediately.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: U.S. Ship Off Yemen Fires Missiles at Houthi Rebel Sites
articles.snippet: The strikes are the first time the United States has directly attacked Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who are fighting the Yemeni government.
articles.abstract: The strikes are the first time the United States has directly attacked Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who are fighting the Yemeni government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American warship stationed off the coast of Yemen fired cruise missiles on Thursday at radar installations that the Pentagon said had been used by Yemeni insurgents to target another American warship in two missile attacks in the last four days.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Two Women Say Donald Trump Touched Them Inappropriately
articles.snippet: The women say they felt compelled to speak after Mr. Trump on Sunday denied ever engaging in such conduct. One says she encountered him on a plane, the other in Trump Tower.
articles.abstract: The women say they felt compelled to speak after Mr. Trump on Sunday denied ever engaging in such conduct. One says she encountered him on a plane, the other in Trump Tower.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was emphatic in the second presidential debate: Yes, he had boasted about kissing women without permission and grabbing their genitals. But he had never actually done those things, he said.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Donald Trump Finds Improbable Ally in WikiLeaks
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, his advisers and many supporters are seizing on emails from Hillary Clinton’s campaign that WikiLeaks has been publishing.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, his advisers and many supporters are seizing on emails from Hillary Clinton’s campaign that WikiLeaks has been publishing.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the final weeks of a dizzying presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump is suddenly embracing an unlikely ally: The document-spilling group WikiLeaks, which Republicans denounced when it published classified State Department cables and Pentagon secrets about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy, David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Creating a Pastry Chef From Scratch
articles.snippet: The demand for people who are practiced in dessert-making is increasing, but the wages of pastry chefs have not kept pace. Restaurants are hiring dessert makers they can train.
articles.abstract: The demand for people who are practiced in dessert-making is increasing, but the wages of pastry chefs have not kept pace. Restaurants are hiring dessert makers they can train.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When it comes to hot jobs in today’s economy, software app developer is almost certainly near the top of the list. Robotics and automotive engineers, too. But pastry chef?

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia, Where Even Milk Depends on Oil, Struggles to Remake Its Economy
articles.snippet: Low crude prices and the war in Yemen have sent a shock through the kingdom’s budget and forced it to revise its social contract even as it seeks to diversify its businesses.
articles.abstract: Low crude prices and the war in Yemen have sent a shock through the kingdom’s budget and forced it to revise its social contract even as it seeks to diversify its businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL KHARJ, Saudi Arabia — This is what it takes to run a mega-dairy in the scorching desert here: 180,000 Holstein cows, precisely cooled cowsheds, water pumped from deep underground, feed from Argentina and a state-of-the-art refrigeration system. To transport chilled milk and other products all over the Arabian Peninsula, add 9,000 vehicles.
